entry.title: Large processing and rendering times spent on simple form validation
entry.content:
Context: this is related to Issue 41485748.
It seems that even [relatively simple, vanilla HTML forms using client side validation](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Forms/Form_validation) i.e. just a `required` attribute, can significantly affect Interaction responsiveness on Android when attempting to submit a form.
For example in [this trace](https://ui.perfetto.dev/#!/?s=848dd0b7f80c49ba3cccc305d9dec70a3887857757c7723f4102d7709e7199c3) (Find the interaction that takes 283ms total duration, close to the end)
...The DOMActivate event is dispatched as part of click (on submit button) which takes 41ms of main thread time on a Pixel 8 device with no throttling. The rendering task that follows is quite fast, but Committing, Activating, and Submitting the animation also takes a long time (unclear if this is just due to the form validation UI or also due to other issues).
One possibility is that the form validation UI appears to start a new opacity animation, which triggers a stream of animation frames and where the first ones "jank" a bit.

entry.title: Browser crash with pathological filters
entry.content:
The attached testcase will bring down the entire browser (Chrome 123.0.6312.123, MacOs), rather than just crashing a tab. The console contains: ``` ... [ERROR:gpu_process_host.cc(999)] GPU process exited unexpectedly: exit_code=10 [FATAL:gpu_data_manager_impl_private.cc(448)] GPU process isn't usable. Goodbye. ```
I bisected this to https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/76eb5175c491e5e1d1f5081371048c473113b5d8. Other filter effects don't seem to bring the whole browser down.

entry.title: Experiment with prioritizing viewport resize before BeginMainFrame
entry.content:
Context: this is related to Issue 41485748, where input focus causes Android Native Keyboard to show/hide, and this causes viewport to resize, with negative effects on rendering performance and INP
[Example trace](https://ui.perfetto.dev/#!/?s=848dd0b7f80c49ba3cccc305d9dec70a3887857757c7723f4102d7709e7199c3) (Find the interaction that takes 283ms total duration, close to the end)
- GestureShowPress (Renderer) invalidates the UI and requests BeginMainFrame - Compositor posts BMF task soon afterwards - GestureTap (Renderer) causes Input focus change, and sends IPC to Browser process - Browser accepts IPC and causes the Keyboard to pop up (Browser process: ManualFillingMediator#transitionIntoState as part of ManualFillingControllerImpl::NotifyFocusedInputChanged) - Browser sends a Viewport resize IPC back down to Renderer - BeginMainFrame is runs first, with HIGHEST priority - Viewport resize is run second, with NORMAL priority - (See WidgetBase::UpdateVisualProperties) - ...this triggers a second BeginMainFrame, and leads to STATE_DROPPED for the previous frame
Since we seem to be dropping the first frame and then re-rendering anyway, we might as well prioritize the resize IPC message higher than the BMF task, I think?

entry.title: input type="number" does not properly localize decimal values according to CLDR rules
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Open the attached index.html file 2. Observe the display formatting of the input value
# Problem Description This is a long-standing problem that, to my knowledge, only Firefox has fixed properly to date. CLDR/ICU contains all the data necessary to properly render numbers according to a given locale's rules. Locales are commonly set by the global `lang` attribute and/or other browser mechanics like language headers.
For HTML <input type="number" /> this localized decimal character functionality seems to be broken / not implemented.
# Summary input type="number" does not properly localize decimal values according to CLDR rules
# Custom Questions #### Which component does this fall under? Not sure - I don't know
#### Does this work in other browsers? Yes - This is just a Chrome problem
# Additional Data Category: API \ Chrome Channel: Not sure \ Regression: No

entry.title: Modernize "Copy to clipboard" on about://media-internals
entry.content:
<Replace this with a summary of the problem. This form is for audio/video issues.>
#### What steps will reproduce the problem? (1) On an Android phone, start Chrome, go to about://media-internals (2) Click a player (3) Try to copy the properties or log by clicking "Copy to clipboard"
#### What is the expected result? It's easy to copy.
#### What is the actual result? The text is selected by default, and the prompt say to use "Ctrl + C" to copy it. However on Android this is not possible, and trying to get the context menu to show "Copy" is tricky.
#### Feature Request: We probably should replace this "Copy to clipboard" behavior with the modernized copy button (see attachment). When clicked, automatically copy things to the clipboard. If user wants to change what's selected before sharing, they can always paste to a text editor and choose what to share.

entry.title: Add settings for CPSS on android
entry.content: Add a dedicated settings for CPSS on Android. Also add support for Messages UI for location permission.

entry.title: Long running tasks or newtork calls are getting rejected in service worker.
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Utilize navigator.serviceWorker.register() to establish a service worker for your web application. The designated task of this service worker is to append an authorization token to service requests. 2. Design a user interface (UI) button that, upon being clicked, activates a function responsible for fetching data from the server. This function is designed to acquire a substantial dataset (e.g., exceeding 2 million records) and present it within the UI. 3. When the server's API request surpasses a 5-minute processing period to handle the extensive dataset, the browser declines the request, resulting in inconsistent behavior.
# Problem Description When tasks or network calls exeeds beyond 5 minutes of processing time, the browser is automatically cancelling them. Interestingly, removing the service worker from the implementation restores the expected behavior. Consequently, we're exploring options to extend or customize the default time limit.
References: a) https://developer.chrome.com/blog/longer-esw-lifetimes b) https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/security/service-worker-security-faq.md#do-service-workers-live-forever
# Additional Comments I have attached a screenshot of a failed network call.
# Summary Long running tasks or newtork calls are getting rejected in service worker.
# Custom Questions #### Which component does this fall under? Blink>ServiceWorker
#### Does this feature work correctly in other browsers? No - I can reproduce the problem in another browser
#### Details of interop issue undefined
# Additional Data Category: API \ Chrome Channel: Stable \ Regression: Yes

entry.title: Canceling mousemove on a document listener cancels drag-and-drop
entry.content:
The mousemove event has no default action. Chrome used to cancel drag-and-drop and text-selection through a cancelled mousemove which was clearly not spec compliant and was fixed through [Issue 40078978](https://issues.chromium.org/40078978).
Apparently the fix missed a corner case: if the event listener is on the document, canceling the event still cancels drag-and-drop. Thanks echen@mozilla.com for spotting this.

entry.title: [CoreML] Support pooling options
entry.content:
Chromium's implementation of pooling operators (`averagePool2d`, `l2Pool2d`, and `maxPool2d`) for the CoreML backend does not support:
- [ ] data types other than "float16" or "float32" - [ ] "NHWC" input layout - [ ] dilations other than [1, 1] - [ ] `ceil_mode`

entry.title: Phase 3: Service-Side Optimizations
entry.content:
This will track various service side optimizations tailored to specific use cases.
With knowledge of client-side pools, implement service-side optimizations such as: Break the 1:1 relationship between shared memory and gpu memory in SharedImage for cases like software video decode, where we want to decode ahead and have 8-16 of shared memory images, but very unlikely need more than 2-3 gpu memory images Proactive texture pre-allocation based on pool sizes. Batching texture creation requests across pools. Intelligent texture eviction considering which pools are actively used by clients. Responding to various GPU signals like memory pressure.

entry.title: Phase 2: Service-Side Implementation and Integration
entry.content: This tracks phase 2 implementation to wire the SI pool details to service side without disrupting the clients usage of pool.

entry.title: Highlight Overriding Stylesheet Filename
entry.content:
Can there be an option in devtools that highlights the stylesheet filename (navPages.scss), if one of the parent folders is in a given list of folders?
This would make it much easier to see at a glance which styles are apart of your overriding styles.
Devtools option: Highlight stylesheets in folder(s): <comma separated string>
Attached example: Highlight stylesheets in folder(s): "AE" (this should highlight 'navPages.scss' because the path contains the parent folder 'AE') (The native navPages.scss filenames would not be highlighted)

entry.title: Phase 1 : Client-Side SharedImagePool
entry.content:
This story tracks the phase 1 implementation which involves :
1. Develop the SharedImagePool class, providing clients with APIs for pool creation, image acquisition, and release. 2. Refactor existing clients (webgl/canvas/webgpu etc.) to utilize this SharedImagePool instead of individually creating/destroying shared images. 3.Profile thoroughly to make sure there are no performance regressions and establish a baseline. 4. Identify and refactor remaining clients to start using the pool and quantify the performance gains even without service-side changes.

entry.title: Make ServiceWorkerContextObserver methods synchronous
entry.content:
Context: [Investigate cases where WorkerIdSet can contain multiple WorkerId for one extension [40936639] - Chromium](https://crbug.com/40936639)
During the above bug, //extensions discovered the only obvious way to accurately track whether a worker is started or stopped is if //extensions has more timely (synchronous) observer notification (outside of //content) of a worker starting or stopping.
It seems all the observer methods were made asynchronous thread safe (base::ObserverListThreadSafe) in order to handle the multi-thread hopping that was happening before ServiceWorkerOnUI. Now that that project is completed, these observer notifications do not need to be asynchronous anymore.
While we're at it, it seems a good idea to just make all the other observer methods synchronous too.
It seems that ServiceWorkerContextWrapper+ServiceWorkerContextCore share these observers in a non-obvious way, so this bug is to simply make them synchronous for the purposes of the blocked bug, and leave the existing sharing in-place for another bug to tackle (if needed).

entry.title: Chrome crashes on my gtk settings
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. create a gtk settings file: ~/.config/gtk-3.0/settings.ini with contents: ``` gtk-cursor-theme-size=24 ``` 2. attempt to launch chrome 3. chrome never launches. If launched from the command line, it prints an error about the gtk settings file not starting with a key, then hangs. I can't give you the exact error because I need to have chrome open to report the bug, but this is a 100% repro. 4. If you remove/rename the settings file, chrome launches normally
# Problem Description see repro steps
# Additional Comments This is actually a "hangs on launch", not a "crash" - but I couldn't find a category for startup issues.
# Summary Chrome crashes on my gtk settings
# Custom Questions #### Crashed report ID: no
#### How much crashed? The whole browser
#### Is it a problem with a plugin? No - It's the browser itself
# Additional Data Category: Crashes \ Chrome Channel: Not sure \ Regression: Yes

entry.title: 40.8% regression in blink_perf.webcodecs at 1285966:1285999
entry.content: None

entry.title: @font-palette-values override-colors accepting non-absolute colors
entry.content: override-colors is specified to only accept absolute colors. System color names are dropped, but currentcolor, light-dark(), and color-mix() with non-absolute colors inside, are not handled correctly.

entry.title: https://developer.android.com/studio/debug/bug-report
entry.content:
This template is for filing bugs against Android System WebView. Chrome bugs should be filed at https://crbug.com/wizard.
Android device name:
Android OS version:
Android System WebView version: (Settings > Apps > the 3 dots in the upper right > Show system. On Android N (7.x) through P (9.0), please include Chrome's version. Otherwise, look for "Android System WebView")
Application: (package name or Play Store URL)
Application version:
Steps to reproduce:
1. 2. 3.
Expected result:
Actual result:
Did this work before? (last working WebView version, or N/A)
---
It's especially helpful if you can capture a bug report right after you experience the bug, and attach it here. See https://developer.android.com/studio/debug/bug-report for instructions.
Screen recordings can also be very helpful - see https://developer.android.com/studio/command-line/adb#screenrecord. Please enable "Show taps" in developer settings.

entry.title: Android OS manager uses the same request ID for all triggers
entry.content:
The first one to complete will successfully have its callback invoked, but any subsequent ones will see that the corresponding callback doesn't exist. This leads to incorrect behavior in the `AttributionManagerImpl` as the callback is invoked *before* all the registrations have been completed, and the `success` value will only reflect the success of the first registration, not any subsequent ones.
https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/attribution_reporting/attribution_os_level_manager_android.cc;l=208-211;drc=291e237516f017c890576f0f0c6edf43bc7d9450
https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/public/android/java/src/org/chromium/content/browser/AttributionOsLevelManager.java;l=371-388;drc=291e237516f017c890576f0f0c6edf43bc7d9450
https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/attribution_reporting/attribution_os_level_manager_android.cc;l=254-256;drc=291e237516f017c890576f0f0c6edf43bc7d9450
